GREAT! All my LTC was sold on the distributed exchange of SuperNet! ^_^

To @Talnicrom: (and anyone else interested)

##How SuperNET's distributed exchange work:

CC1 = Crypto Currency 1 (the one you want to sell)
CC2 = the one you want to get
https://nxt.org/
http://www.supernet.org/index.php

1. You make NXT wallet and register it in SuperNET app.
2. SuperNET app generates wallets for your SuperCurrecies.
3. You send CC1 from your normal wallet to SuperNET's.
4. SuperNET gives you the same amount of SuperCC1 in NXT's Asset Exchange.
5. You sell your SuperCC1 at the exchange and get NXT.
6. You buy SuperCC2 for NXT.
7. The amount you bought appears in your SuperNET app.
8. You specify a wallet to receive CC2 and SuperNET sends you CC2 there.

You can experiment by buying some LTC that I sell. I set it at the current price at non-distributed exchange, so it should be fine.

Sadly, SuperNET does not support NMC.

A (already not so) short story before bed time.

I was a teacher once. My university has several schools for children who want extra education (normal school is usually not enough to pass exams in a good university). There are paid ones and a free one. Paid are run by moneybags (like any other school) and have teachers like any other school. The free one is run by a collective of university lecturers, governed and protected by another lecturer, and has student activists to hold classes with children after lectures. Neither get paid there, and all the (little) money the university shares is used to provide children with good education without telling them to pay for it.

So the thing happened with my second (third?) "elder" (you've got to teach the teachers, so there are elders and apprentices among students). Usually there is only one and then you become elder yourself - I could not do it, but I really wanted, so people tried to help me all they could. He was explaining me what I have done right and wrong (mostly wrong), and I have said "I'm really sorry I can't do better. I try though. But at least we don't take money for it!" - the last part was intended as a joke, but the answer was something to remember:

-- The fact that we don't ask for money is not a reason to do it bad, it is a reason to do it the best we can. Because we have to deal not only with the regular folk, but also with those who want to be educated and want to go to the university, but can't pay for it. For those we are the last and only hope. The rest are not any different, because now they don't have time to switch schools. So if the teacher can't do the work good enough, they are doomed. You see, it's not about you. It's about that kid that won't pass the exams because you told that you want to teach him, but have not given him required skills and knowledge.

That's also why no one gets paid - so that there was no extra motivation to do the job.

That was one of the first times I felt the responsibility for others, and it felt like as if someone was strangling me. Had a hard time breathing for some time after those words... Never liked the idea that someone goes down because of me. And when I got into my university thanks to a great job my teachers did, it was a great shame and a burden to realize that someone won't be able to pass the exams because of me.

That's why when they have fired me, I felt relieved. Guess that's what they call "relieved of duty")

Before I thought that on my ancient machine, high FPS won't be an issue, but I was really wrong: even on games that lag sometimes as soon as they stop lagging, FPS booms over 100. ##Something to think about.

Let's say there is [this thing](http://127.0.0.1:43110/13gwtosUWbE8td7WQJkRHYBAM3JrxqEmxr/). (WARNING, fast canvas graphics, possibly too fast for mobile platforms!)
(I'm not sure my PC is easily reachable through my router, IPS and other f...ers, so write if you can't load the thing for more than X minutes)

All it does is calculates mouse position on the screen, translates it to the position on the canvas and draws a circle. And repeats that 60 times per second. Why? Stupid question. Because I can.

The thing is that with 60 FPS the circle should follow the mouse exactly, but it does not. It lags about 40-50 frames after, but is not any kind of laggy - it moves fluidly, only not fast enough to catch the cursor.

If you move the cursor once or twice, you possibly won't even see that, but if you move the cursor in large ~~circles (or squares?)~~ lines (but repeatedly), fast (but not too fast) , then you'll see what I'm writing about.

My question is why, and unlike previous why, this one smells like a smart one so I propose thinking about it.

Closest I got to the explanation is here:
http://www.tek-tips.com/viewthread.cfm?qid=1669180

There it is said that the cursor is drawn to the screen separately, so it is possible that there is some lag between real movement and the way a browser (or any other app) is reacting to it.

And idea for media zites: make clients download several random media files {on the first login}/{from time to time} so that there would never be dead media even if the zite is several GB large.

Another way is to have an in-zite database of how many users have each media file and make people DL the ones that are unpopular. It can be done by publishing a list of files held by each user (should be a file for each device), then those files can be parsed to calculate what media is popular, what media was downloaded because it's not popular and what media should be downloaded in order to be accessible. Of course only the fresh files should be counted. Otherwise  there will be hundreds of sync-failed files for each user, or many files will be counted as downloaded long after user has left the service.

You know what would be useful? The "don't believe this commit" flag. Like you publish content with this flag and receiver won't use your PC when it is searching for the last version.  Not only that, but because this (flagged) content is still signed by you and obviously legit, it would follow your order and clean the commit flagged as "this" - for example your previous synchronisation. The receiver would instead search for the previous version on the nets if it still exists. And that's where some other sleepy receiver awakens and without knowing it he streams older version to all those who have a flagged content. Because it it the latest legit version without a flag that's awailable on the nets.

In the end I have decided that I was misusing the whole thing. PGP is not the thing for storing files. It is made for safe transfer of data. For example, if I want to transfer secret documents from computer A to computer B, I can use GPG to easily encrypt/decrypt stuff. The document will be then safe from the moment of encryption till the moment of reception. But when GPG is being used to store data securely, reception happens right after encryption. So the data is not secure. (Unless you delete the key manually).

On the other hand, if GPG is installed on a flash drive, one can encrypt/decrypt any data wherever it is needed.

I found a new way of bug hunting: artification. There was a programm that drew dots at predefined positions. Very basic thing, but also very important for my task. And it had to be a bug-proof basement for anything I make from it. So I made it do aomething completely out of normal range of tasks. I made it draw a picture out of those dots. As before I used different elevation/signal strengh to make different colors. And during this excercise I've found several important bugs that I would not find any other way. Also there were few code optimisations and reworks that allowed more flexibility and more ease of access to important functions.

Similar things have happened before when I have creted those "flowers", but since they were mainly accidents and I made no big effort to work on them as any kind of art, results were fewer. Still there were results so I annpunce this as a working method. At least working for me.

Teach man to catch fish and he will be fed for the rest of his life. But what if you have to teach a boy? A boy that hates school and more than school he hates only homework.

My solution is shortly described as "don't". Not just that - refuse him ability to do it. And when he gets negative marks at school, make it obvious for him why is that happening, but still don't help him. Don't help until he asks you to. Until you see that it is what he really wants.

That idea was born from an obvious truth that people know - you can't teach anyone against his will. It is possible to train human like a dog, or parrot, but that can berely be called teaching and I don't think it's either fair (both to a teacher and a student) or humane.

Realisation of the idea was a bit more complicated, since my parents ask, plead and command me to help my brother with his homework. But having quite a nasty character, I told them no. Usually they would ask me extremely politely at first, less politely afterwards and scream later, to no result until today.

Today the request was a touch different: grandmother came to my room and very softly asked me whether I can listen to how my brother reads texts of his English homework. "He may read if he want. Not like I shall stop him anyway." And so he came, **glad** that he got a permission, and read everything, twice or three times if I thought it was required and read again when I told him he can do it again if he thinks he need it. When I ~~told~~ adviced him to write down how to pronounce some words, he jumped and run to get a pencil on the bounce. And when "the lesson" was over, he kissed my cheek and thanked me. So I call it a success.

Of course there is a question of quality - when he came, it was my turn not to fuck up so I've kept my ears tuned to the maximum, attention on him etc. while also making it look as if I was listening casually, and I am still not sure he got it all and that he won't get another negative mark... but what is a mark anyway? The kid wanted to do stuff! Not like he wanted to know English or anything like it, but at least he wanted to make his job well. That is enough. There is at least some motivation now AND he is in a good mood (unlike what mood he is in when mother comes to check his homework..)

@Shellbound: I disagree. LVM adds convenience (if you manage to set it up... I was too harsh when I chose not to use it at all. Simply placing /home there would be both easy and useful.)

You don't have to use it often, but it adds much needed agility when it comes to partitioning. Plus making backups with LVM should also be easier.

It may be not needed sometimes - on a notebook, for example. But when it comes to PC, LVM seems a very nice idea. For example, I would make a raid-like volume for my data (may be 3 HDD for important things - LVM is very agile), and spread the rest of the data between 3 HDD without mirroring. And the great part is that it would be only 1 LVM partition on each LVM - and I would NEVER need to change their sizes with any parted or gdisk, I would never be afraid to loose my data - LVM promise that they handle it with care.

It is not the most important thing one could imagine - yes.. But it is a cool thing non the less.

Too bad it's so hard for me to set it up on Arch and that Windows does not have native support of it (but then windows also does not support ext4...).

Another way is to archive some posts:
Post marked as archive should be sent into a separate file, named as temporary archive. When it's size is above some limit, rename it into something like archive-\[some code] and make it optional. And do both: let users mark posts as archived on their own and make old posts archived automaticly.

That way there won't be too many files laying around which is currently a big problem with ZeroMail.

I don't know how to make that work well without too many files laying around though.
